pageContext.claim: “Anthony [Fauci] is a good person, very good person. I've disagreed with him. When I closed the border to China, he disagreed with that. And then ultimately he agreed. And he said I saved hundreds of thousands of lives, which is what happened. Everybody disagreed when I did that.”
pageContext.analysis: False. Fauci never said it would "blow over," and in fact was warning consistently about long-term risks from the covid-19 outbreak. Trump is also giving a false account of the decision-making process that led to his Jan. 31 ban on foreign travelers from China. Although Fauci and other public health advisers initially opposed the travel restrictions, they ended up endorsing them before Trump. At a news briefing Feb. 7, Alex Azar, the secretary of health and human services, said the travel restrictions “were the uniform recommendation of the career public health officials here at HHS,” specifically naming Fauci and Robert Redfield, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. “This was their considered recommendation, which I and the president adopted,” Azar said.
